docs.lead_paragraph: West Nile virus, the mosquito-borne illness that for a year has scared people in and around New York, is harder to detect than generally realized, researchers say. A report in the current issue of Neurology urged greater vigilance in diagnosing the disease, citing two patients who exhibited unusual symptoms and so were found to have the disease only after a delay.

headline.main: Vigilance Urged in Detecting Nile Virus

docs.abstract: Researchers say West Nile virus, mosquito-borne illness that for a year has scared people in and around New York, is harder to detect than generally realized; cite two cases of delayed diagnosis (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Do you want to keep eating, even if it means dying of pneumonia? That was the question I posed to Mr. C. as he ate the rest of his lunch. Yes, he replied without hesitation. A wizened 77-year-old with fiery eyes, he had been admitted to the hospital short of breath. It wasn't clear why. He did not smoke and had no cough. There was nothing suggesting asthma, pneumonia, congestive heart failure or other common causes of shortness of breath.

headline.main: A Remedy Not Worth The Pain

docs.abstract: Sandeep Jauhar article on swallowing dysfunction that can develop with age or disease and allow food to be aspirated into the lungs, with risk of fatal pneumonia; says there is a new concern today about using a feeding tube to eliminate the risk; recalls a patient of his who rejected a tube rather than forgo the pleasures of eating (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A common antibiotic that has been around for decades may help people who suffer from Huntington's disease, a debilitating hereditary ailment. Although researchers emphasized that much study remained to be done, they said the drug, minocycline, a relative of tetracycline, did much to slow the course of the disease in mice.

headline.main: An Old Antibiotic Generates New Hopes

docs.abstract: Minocycline, an antibiotic that has been around for decades, shows promise in treating people who suffer from Huntington's disease (S)
docs.snippet: A common antibiotic that has been around for decades may help people who suffer from Huntington's disease, a debilitating hereditary ailment.    Although researchers emphasized that much study remained to be done, they said the drug, minocycline, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: The next time a doctor wants to take a blood sample from your thumb, tell him to stick it in the ear. The idea here is not to encourage impoliteness but to reduce pain. Reporting in The British Medical Journal, a group of doctors in England said they had determined that taking a blood sample from the ear lobe instead of the thumb was less painful.

headline.main: For a Drop of Blood, Take It in the Ear

docs.abstract: British researchers report that it is less painful to take a blood samples from the ear lobe than from the thumb; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The next time a doctor wants to take a blood sample from your thumb, tell him to stick it in the ear.    The idea here is not to encourage impoliteness but to reduce pain. Reporting in The British Medical Journal, a group of doctors in England said...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, people meet up with a jarring reminder that they are not as young as they think. Increasingly, the jolt hits middle-age types when a doctor walks through the door: he or she is not Marcus Welby, in keeping with the demographics of the medical profession. Of the 621,000 doctors practicing in hospitals or offices in 1998, the year for which the most recent data are available, almost half were under age 45, according to the American Medical Association. The greatest proportion -- about 189,108 -- were 35 to 44.

headline.main: When the Cardiologist Has a Baby Face

docs.abstract: People in their 30's and 40's sometimes find it hard to accept a doctor younger than they or younger than they are used to; some question clinical and life experience of younger doctors and are unprepared to take their advice; younger doctors can also trigger insecurities about age, mortality and achievements; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The only things scorpions inspire in most people are fear and a desire to get out of the way of their poison-tipped stingers. But researchers at the University of California at Irvine say they have developed a chemical that works like scorpion venom, but instead of harming people, it may one day help doctors who perform organ transplants or treat autoimmune diseases like lupus and arthritis.

headline.main: The Kinder Side of a Scorpion Sting

docs.abstract: Researchers at University of California at Irvine develop a chemical that works like scorpion venom, and they say it may one day help doctors who perform organ transplants or treat autoimmune diseases like lupus and arthritis; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In all the vast territory of the American health care system, there is nothing quite like the African Women's Health Practice of the obstetrics and gynecology department at Brigham and Women's Hospital here. Every Friday, dozens of African women immigrants, now living in the area but still wearing the brilliant gowns of their native countries, come here for help with their medical problems. Many are seeking not just routine care in the specialty, but treatment for special gynecologic conditions related to female circumcision.

headline.main: A Life Devoted to Stopping The Suffering of Mutilation

docs.abstract: Dr Nawal M Nour discusses the work of the clinic she founded at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston to help African women suffering from gynecological conditions related to female circumcision; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: You're not getting older, you're getting better. At least psychologically. That's the argument put forth in a new study by a University of California psychologist, who says most people become better adjusted as they age. Which is not to say they are necessarily any happier.

headline.main: Older and Better, With Firmer Footing

docs.abstract: Dr Constance J Jones of University of California in Fresno reports that most people become better adjusted as they age; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical experiments involving people at the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center at Tulsa have been suspended on the orders of federal investigators who found numerous safety and ethics violations. The action was taken by the Office for Human Research Protections of the Department of Health and Human Services, after an investigation showed that about 100 patients in one experiment were injected with a vaccine that had been made by unqualified laboratory workers and had never been safety-tested, and other violations. The suspension was first reported yesterday in USA Today.
docs.abstract: Federal investigators halt medical experiments involving people at the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center at Tulsa, citing safety and ethics violations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, 13-year-old Drew Williams's asthma was so severe, he could not even go to a movie. Once a fleck of dog dander, a remnant from a pet-owner who previously had his seat, sparked an attack. At school in Dillon, Colo., Drew's desk had to be far from classmates who owned furry animals. And that was despite high doses of asthma medications he took every morning to open his airways.

headline.main: Working to Block Allergens at the Source of the Attack

docs.abstract: Encouraging results are reported with experimental asthma and allergy treatment called anti-IgE, which is aimed at stopping attacks at their source in the immune system rather than merely treating symptoms; photo (M)
